item.title: Moore Archives & Preservation LLC
item.content:encoded:
We MAP the past for your future

As the internet expands, so too does the amount of users and what they do online. Historians, genealogists, hobbyists, writers, and students are some of the most prolific internet researchers today. Many of them conduct their research internationally, and cannot afford the time or funds to travel to your location to conduct the research they need- so how can you reach them?

Moore Archives & Preservation was founded on the belief that no organization should be worried about their valuable letters, maps, and books' preservation for the coming generations. We founded this company because we want to provide that service to you at an accessible price. We want to handle your irreplaceable organization's relics in a careful and conscientious manner, to preserve and digitize your family heirlooms without the risk of them receiving further damage. We share your concern for collections, and as academics, researchers and conservationists, we handle them with the same care and love as you do.

MAP follows the standard practices outlined by the American Institute for Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works (AIC) and the Library of Virginia Standards for handling and processing collections. We are constantly striving to improve our skills, and are dedicated to expanding our knowledge and experiences as the technology evolves.

We are dedicated to helping you preserve and digitize your collection at an accessible price, and for qualified organizations, we offer grant writing assistance. Get in touch with us to set up a consultation, or use the contact form at the bottom of this page to inquire whether our services are right for you.

Learn More

item.title: About
item.content:encoded:
Kristi Moore, CEO

Kristi has 15 years of experience in research, writing and digital file management. She has two years of specialized experience in document and paper conservation, with a bachelor's degree in Historic Preservation and Anthropology from the University of Mary Washington. Her education includes one year overseas study of anthropology and archaeology at the University of Cambridge, UK, internships with the Library of Congress and the Fredericksburg Circuit Courthouse Archives, training in archaeological collection processing with the Veteran's Curation Program, and training from The Mission Continues Fellowship program at the Library of Congress Packard Campus.

Mrs. Moore served in the U.S. Army from 2001-2005, and deployed to Baghdad in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom. She spent the subsequent decade as a DoD analyst focusing on issues in the Middle East and South America. Moore Archives & Preservation LLC is a certified SWaM located in Fredericksburg, VA.

 

 

Get in touch

We know that finding a thorough, affordable archivist can be difficult. Contact us to see how we can work with your budget.

Book an appointment ▸

item.title: Services
item.content:encoded:
Areas of Expertise

 

Archives Program Establishment

Offering a free survey and estimate of your collection, we can help you establish basic policies and structures for effective retrieval and item tracking. We offer full rehousing of your collection and finding aids, to ensure the most logical storage solutions to facilitate the archives' use.

Digitization

Collections are photographed or scanned to provide a digital record of their contents and extent of damage (if applicable). This is vital for inventory and insurance records, and for makingyour collection available online to a wider audience.

Web Hosting Coming Soon!

Soon, we will have a database to host your digital records on your behalf, for reference, searching and ease of access.

Documents

We have experience in handling documents up to 330 years old, in varying states of disrepair. UsingpH neutral conservation methods, we can reconstruct your document from fragments, stabilizing the structure for further handling needed to digitize and store.

Documentation

Most items in a collection are associated with acquisition paperwork, records of ownership, or a finding aid. If you need any of these, we can provide assistance in creating them. If you have a database for tracking items in your collection, we can perform data entry and other necessary data input to support it.

Photographic Media

MAP offers cleaning, rehousing, documentation and digitizing of photographic media- including slides and negatives. Images will be optimized for personal or web use, with services such as watermarks, resizing, or touch-up available.

Books

At our facility we offer cleaning, page mending, documentation and rehousing. We also work with the finest local bookbinders to provide binding repair and rebinding services.

 

We follow all AIC standards for material handling and repair, and guarantee that all items will be handled with care and diligence.

item.title: Contact
item.content:encoded:
Contact us for rates

Depending on the work needed, we charge an hourly rate or a daily rate. An estimate will be provided at the beginning of our work, outlining estimated work hours, materials costs, and other expenses. We require 50% deposit before beginning work to allow for purchase of necessary materials, and will bill for the remaining work at the end. Our technicians keep detailed logs of the time they spend on your collection, and will provide a detailed work log at the end of your project. Should we encounter an unexpected expense while working on your project, we will notify you immediately, make recommendations, and come to a solution that will fit your budget.

Book an appointment

Use the form below to tell us about your archival needs, and we’ll call you back to schedule an appointment. Please be as detailed as possible. To help us best serve your inquiry, we recommend that you first describe the issue you’re having before telling us what you want to achieve. You may also email or call us to make an appointment. Our general response time is one business day.

item.title: LoC
item.content:encoded:
Music Industry Publications

We do volunteer work for the Library of Congress Packard Campus, assisting in processing U.S. and British music publications. The following collections are examples of themes and brands of interest we've seen while inventorying and assessing damage to the publications. The majority of the publications span from 1940-1985, and include rock music magazines such as Crawdaddy, Pop Weekly, Circus, Hullabaloo, and Fusion.

All image contents are copyright to the owners.

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="2500.0"] While working at the Library of Congress, I grabbed some snapshots of the incredible ads by Fender in the late 1960s and early 1970s.[/caption]
Learn More
[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="496.0"] The 1972 Election cycle saw the first time citizens 18-21 years old were able to vote; here is a curious set of artifacts from the voter registration effort.[/caption]
Learn More

item.title: Hagerstown Almanacs
item.content:encoded: [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="2324.0"] This is an almanac from Hagerstown Maryland, dated 1833. It's a sewn folio, and in order to preserve it, we need to remove the pin from the binding and the sewing.[/caption]

item.title: Courthouse Archives
item.content:encoded: [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="2448.0"] This is a 218-year-old court document in desperate need of stabilization. There are tears, damage from folding, acidic damage and water damage.[/caption] [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="2448.0"] The document was mended with heat-set mulberry fiber tissue. Following basic preservation standards, all alterations to the document are fully reversible. This document is now stable enough to be handled, examined, digitized, and stored for another century.[/caption]

item.title: 1972 Election
item.content:encoded:
(Originally Published in the Library of Congress Blog Now See Hear!)

Researched and written by Kristi Moore

Eighteen years before, MTV’s “Rock the Vote” targeted potential young Americans in their campaign to increase political involvement, the record industry took the initiative to help register young voters, using the famous names and faces that appealed to the youth population.

On July 1, 1971, the 26th Amendment became part of the United States Constitution, granting voting rights to people eighteen and older. This allowed a new demographic to participate in both the primaries and the presidential election of 1972, one directly affected by the ongoing war in Vietnam.  Youth were protesting the Vietnam War and the draft, and with the impending election, tensions were high. The anti-war movement was widespread among youth, and was reflected through art, music, and frequent protest marches and demonstrations. The presidential candidates were South Dakota Senator George McGovern (D) and incumbent President Richard Nixon (R). Many younger voters were attracted to McGovern’s anti-war stance.

In March 1972, Billboard Magazine ran a special article concerning young voters, providing information to record labels, disc jockeys and politically-interested musicians with ideas and information on how to connect with this audience of young voters with strong political ideas. In an effort to register the significant numbers of newly-eligible Americans, record companies and musicians encouraged the population to exercise their new rights. Some voiced support for a particular candidate, while others remained more neutral, choosing to simply encourage voters to register. The record labels who were the most demonstrative about their encouragement in printed ads were Ampex, Apple, A&M, United Artists Records, and Polydor, with clients such as Joan Baez, John Lennon and Yoko Ono, ELO and James Brown.

The Beach Boys were one of the most politically active music groups, registering approximately 80,000 young voters by March 1972. They were so passionate about the vote that their contract demanded the right to set up registrations at their concerts. The music group Chicago also held voter registration events at their concerts, and printed state-by-state voting guidelines inside the jacket of their best-selling Carnegie Hall Live album. The music industry supported voter registration events in a variety of ways, including contests and prizes, competitions, radio public service announcements, free records, print advertising, and concert refunds.

Actor Warren Beatty organized fundraising concerts and voter registration events, tailoring McGovern’s appeal to the younger population. Performers such as Barbra Streisand, James Taylor, Carole King, Joni Mitchell, Ike & Tina Turner and The Grateful Dead agreed to play for the concerts. Defunct groups reunited for concerts, including Simon & Garfunkel, Peter, Paul and Mary, and comedy duo Mike Nichols and Elaine May. Altogether, the benefit concerts raised nearly $1.5m for McGovern.

The Boston Globe wrote “Among other things, the 1972 presidential campaign may go down in history as the country’s most star-studded of all time.” Despite the efforts of the music and film industry, only approximately 36% of people aged 18-21 registered and voted that year, and Nixon won the election by a landslide.

 

SOURCES

Billboard Magazine (1972). “Youth Voter Registration Report.” 11 March 1972.

Cobb, Nathan (1972). “Mary Travers: she’s vocal for McGovern.” The Boston Globe. May 28 1972.

Hay, R. Couri (2015). “New again: Warren Beatty.” Interview Magazine. June, 1972.

Italie, Hillel (2012). “McGovern’s anti-war candidacy was a cultural landmark.” Associated Press. 22 October 2012.

Ortega, Tony (1972). “Warren Beatty sexes up George McGovern.” Village Voice. 27 April 1972.

Roberts, Steven (1972). “Film and music stars raise $300,000 at a McGovern concert.” The New York Times. 17 April 1972.

item.title: Rock Magazine Ads for... Crabs?
item.content:encoded:
In our volunteer work at the Library of Congress (Packard Campus), there was apparently much to be gleaned about American culture from the 1970s rock magazines we inventoried.

Initially, it seemed a bit absurd. Why would rock magazines be advertising a chemical solution for lice and other body parasites? Could this be related to the "free love" movement of 1960s and 70s? Was there an outbreak?

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="2500.0"] One of many ads for A-200 Pyrinate gel.[/caption]

A bit of research reveals that up until 1972, DDT was the preferred insecticide for body lice. It was widely used, most famously in prison and military situations. Come 1972, research suggested that DDT might not be the best to use on humans, as it builds up in adipose tissue rather than passing out of the body. Too much DDT buildup is toxic to humans, and was eventually blamed for increased risk of developmental delay in children, increased cancer chances, and male infertility- not to mention the serious environmental hazards.

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1600.0"] Gratuitous screen shot from the incredible movie Shawshank Redemption (Copyright Columbia Pictures and Castle Rock Entertainment)[/caption]

In 1972, the EPA issued a "cancellation order" on DDT use. With DDT out of the picture, there was a significant gap in the market for treating body lice. It appears that A200 Pyrinate was simply capitalizing on the opening in the market at that time.

Having an archives of rock music magazines from the 1970s enables us to rediscover medical research history and unique cultural "gems" like this one!

Sources:

https://www.epa.gov/ingredients-used-pesticide-products/ddt-brief-history-and-status, accessed 12/20/2016.

http://www.panna.org/resources/ddt-story, accessed 12/23/2016.
item.dc:creator: kristi@moorearchives.com

item.title: A 215-year-old volume of Plutarch's Lives- Rebound!
item.content:encoded:
On November 30th, 2016, we began preservation on a volume entitled Plutarch's Lives Volume VI, published in 1801. The volume was leather bound, hardback, and suffered from extensive dry rot of both the leather and the strings and cord tying the book together.

The first order of business was to take it apart- that meant cutting the strings, cutting the text block out of the case, and separating all the signatures (each section of pages folded together) carefully, without getting any of the pages out of order, or losing loose pages.

Second, we needed to clean and mend the pages, using preservation-quality cleaning tools and a heat-set mulberry tissue to invisibly repair the damage. This type of repair can remain visible, but the goal is to stabilize the paper so it can continue to be handled (gently!) without causing further damage. It can be visually unappealing at times, but it is the best way to go without pasting it to something, as there is also information written on the back. Most of the cleaning involved the spine, as the leather casing had been glued to it.

Third, we need to bind it. Since the many of the pages were torn or disintegrated at the fold in the signatures, I couldn't bind it the same way- so I used a modified whip stitch for binding. First, I found a few sources identifying or teaching this method, and compared notes. Everyone has their own way of doing things, and there are modifications you can make to nearly everything in order to adapt the binding for the needs of the volume. Since the edges of the papers were brittle, I'd have to sew through more secure areas of the paper- through the face.

Many bookbinders use an awl for this purpose, but as I have access to a drill press, I carefully drilled each hole through the book. This was a little nerve-wracking, as drilling through a 215-year-old book is not something I take lightly. Being a bibliophile is hard sometimes!

bibliophile: noun
bib·lio·phile \ˈbi-blē-ə-ˌfī(-ə)l\
A lover of books especially for qualities of format; also :  a book collector

Using a hefty thread that I waxed myself, I began to stitch. I used undyed linen yarn for my cords, allowing for the diameter and size of the cords to take and redistribute some of the pressure from the stitching, which will make the spine of the book stronger.

 

Then, I cut the end boards to size, drilled holes for where the cords will thread through, and glued them in place. I left the book with a weighty tome of Abraham Lincoln's Biography on top.

Now we need to figure out- should it be bound in leather or cloth? Or cloth with a leather spine? I haven't decided yet, so you and Plutarch (and all of his Lives) will have to wait to see.
item.excerpt:encoded: Take a look at a 215-year-old book go through a transformation! From old and broken and rotted, to... not so broken or rotted. Still old, though.
item.dc:creator: kristi@moorearchives.com

item.title: Why Religious Organizations Need Archives Work
item.content:encoded:
There is an extensive history of churches in Virginia- some dating back to the mid 1600s. With old structures come old records- the church registry, with its baptisms and marriages, historic letters and books, and perhaps an original blueprint or floor plan. Not only is this information valuable to the parishioners, but to genealogists, academics, researchers, historians and architects.

Places of worship like the St. Luke's Church at Smithfield, the historic Aquia Church, and the Bedford Historic Meeting House all hold vital information on the history of colonization, early building techniques, membership records, and the culture of the people who attended that building at any time of its history.

Church registries are a gold mine for genealogists, and I'm certain each and every religious organization has had researchers request access to the records. Depending on the age and time the record book was assembled, each person handling the book causes a degree of damage. Oil from human hands, carelessness with the paper, exposure to sun and other environmental pollutants, and repeated pulling from a shelf or drawer- each of these causes its own kind of damage to the item.

Moore Archives & Preservation was founded in part to assist organizations in preserving these vital records. We can restore, stabilize, clean and mend your church registry- and to help with future research requirements, we offer full digitization services. After we take care of your records, you can store it safely, and researchers may be granted full access to a digital image of the item. This will save your priceless records from excessive handling, ensuring its life is extended.

In the event of a disaster, your organization will have records of these important papers and books, and not lose priceless information contained within. The digital record can be held at your facility, or on our database, ensuring the continued preservation and research value of our history. The digital record will additionally assist in insurance claims, should it become necessary.

If you're interested, please contact us for a consultation. Consultations and estimates are free, and we are willing to work with your organization on payment. If you qualify, we can help you apply for grants to fund the archival work. We are flexible enough to negotiate work time- we can do the work in pieces as funding allows, spreading the work over several months or years. We believe very strongly in the value of historic records, and will accommodate your needs.

Contact us for a free estimate
item.dc:creator: kristi@moorearchives.com

item.title: The Supreme Court Goes to Rehab
item.content:encoded:
This week I'm working on an old volume entitled  "Reports of cases in the Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia."  This is volume CII,  from November 19, 1903, to September 15, 1904,  Richmond: J. H. O'Bannon, superintendent of public printing. 1904. 

  The condition of this volume is pretty poor, the leather bound case has dry rot, and both covers have fallen off.  

Initially, I thought reattachment of the covers would be the extent of the repair needed, and proceeded to remove all of the glue on the binding. 

A few of the signatures had come loose from one another, but I had hoped to be able to sew them back together. Unfortunately, in my efforts I found that the cord used in the binding had such extensive dry rot that not even using linen thread to tie it together would do the job anymore. This needs to be rebound.  

 In separating the signatures, I am finding that there is some pencil writing on some of the leaves, as well as minor tears and acid damage. On page 314, notes in the margin are in ink. 

Pages in need of mending:

beginning - p.33, p.434, 546, 625, 962, 978, 994

single pages-  xv, xvii 847, 1009

Repairs:

looking at the repairs needed, I don't have quite the right paper. Using my sample books, I'm considering

Japanese Conservation, Mending and Hinging Tissues and Papers

12gsm Uso Mino Thin (Kizukishi) TPB077001

15gsm Uso Mino (Kizuki) TPB076001

16gsm Yame Kozo Hadaura S-2 TPB166002

 

Japanese Fine Art Tissues and Papers

18gsm Toso Kozo TPB078001

 

Japanese Roll Paper

5gsm Tengujo Thin TPB194002

Until I get more papers to mend with, I'm making do with small pieces of machine-made Tengucho paper tinted with Golden Acrylics Yellow Ochre and wheat starch paste.  

Sewing- this may be the largest volume I've resewn. Because so little of the original binding remained, I chose to use the original holes in the signatures, and sew on cords of linen, with beeswax-coated linen binding thread.
item.dc:creator: kristi@moorearchives.com
